1.1. Methods related with USBtin¶

The following methods just involve functions of USBtin and the communication User <—> USBtin.

Methods¶

USBTin.openSerial()¶

Performs a series of actions to establish a communication between the user (PC) and USBtin:

  1. Open the serial port.
  2. Initialize Periodic Thread for Finite State Machine function
Parameters:
None
Returns:
None (Print to the console if port is opened or it have raised an exception)
USBTin.closeSerial()¶

Performs a series of actions to end the communication between the user (PC) and USBtin:

  1. Stop Periodic Thread for Finite State Machine function
  2. Close the CAN channel (if it is opened
  3. Close the serial port
Parameters:
None
Returns:
None (Print to the console when the port is closed)
USBTin.askHWversion()¶

Get hardware USBtin version.

Parameters:
None
Returns:
String indicating hardware version
USBTin.askFWversion()¶

Get firmware USBtin version.

Parameters:
None
Returns:
String indicating hardware version
USBTin.askUSBstatus()¶

Read status/error flag of can controller

Parameters:
None
Returns:

Fxx[CR] with xx as hexadecimal byte with following error flags:

Bit 0 - not used

Bit 1 - not used

Bit 2 - Error warning (Bit EWARN of MCP2515)

Bit 3 - Data overrun (Bit RX1OVR or RX0OVR of MCP2515)

Bit 4 - not used

Bit 5 - Error-Passive (Bit TXEP or RXEP of MCP2515)

Bit 6 - not used

Bit 7 - Bus error (Bit TXBO of MCP2515)

USBTin.SerialSetTimestamping(x)¶

Set time stamping on/off

Parameters:
  • x (bin):

0: off 1: on

Returns:
None (Print to the console if the Time stamping is now on/off/or there is an input error)
USBTin.ReadResponse()¶

Reads and process elements (responses) from RPSqueue (instance attribute)

Parameters:
None
Returns:
  • Different strings or constants depending on the response to previous messages (indicated on each method)
